column2: He appears almost to prefer equine to human companionship, and he is as fond of being among horses as the Collie is of being in the midst of sheep.
column3: He appears almost to prefer equine to human companionship, and he is as fond of being among horses as the Collie is of being in the midst of sheep.

column2: Yet he is of friendly disposition, and it must be insisted that he is by no means so destitute of intelligence as he is often represented to be.
column3: Yet he is of friendly disposition, and it must be insisted that he is by no means so destitute of intelligence as he is often represented to be.

column2: On the contrary, he is capable of being trained into remarkable cleverness, as circus proprietors have discovered.
column3: On the contrary, he is capable of being trained into remarkable cleverness, as circus proprietors have discovered.

column2: Of late years, however, these dogs have so far degenerated as to be looked upon simply as companions, or as exhibition dogs, for only very occasionally can it be found that any pains have been taken to train them systematically for gun-work.
column3: Of late years, however, these dogs have so far degenerated as to be looked upon simply as companions, or as exhibition dogs, for only very occasionally can it be found that any pains have been taken to train them systematically for gun work.

column2: At that period they were looked upon as a novelty, and, though the generosity and influence of a few admirers ensured separate classes being provided for the breed at the leading shows, it did not necessitate the production of such perfect specimens as those which a few years afterwards won prizes.
column3: At that period they were looked upon as a novelty, and, though the generosity and influence of a few admirers ensured separate classes being provided for the breed at the leading shows, it did not necessitate the production of such perfect specimens as those which a few years afterwards won prizes.

column2: Berolina.
column3: Berolina.

column2: In appearance the Dalmatian should be very similar to a Pointer except in head and marking.
column3: In appearance the Dalmatian should be very similar to a Pointer except in head and marking.

column2: Those which are flesh-coloured in this particular should be discarded, however good they may be in other respects.
column3: Those which are flesh coloured in this particular should be discarded, however good they may be in other respects.

column2: The density and pureness of colour, in both blacks and browns, is of great importance, but should not be permitted to outweigh the evenness of the distribution of spots on the body; no black patches, or even mingling of the spots, should meet with favour, any more than a ring-tail or a clumsy-looking, heavy-shouldered dog should command attention.
column3: The density and pureness of colour, in both blacks and browns, is of great importance, but should not be permitted to outweigh the evenness of the distribution of spots on the body; no black patches, or even mingling of the spots, should meet with favour, any more than a ring tail or a clumsy looking, heavy shouldered dog should command attention.

column2: The clearer and whiter they are the better they are likely to be.
column3: The clearer and whiter they are the better they are likely to be.

column2: There should not be the shadow of a mark or spot on them.
column3: There should not be the shadow of a mark or spot on them.

column2: When about a fortnight old, however, they generally develop a dark ridge on the belly, and the spots will then begin to show themselves; first about the neck and ears, and afterwards along the back, until at about the sixteenth day the markings are distinct over the body, excepting only the tail, which frequently remains white for a few weeks longer.
column3: When about a fortnight old, however, they generally develop a dark ridge on the belly, and the spots will then begin to show themselves; first about the neck and ears, and afterwards along the back, until at about the sixteenth day the markings are distinct over the body, excepting only the tail, which frequently remains white for a few weeks longer.

column2: The standard of points as laid down by the leading club is sufficiently explicit to be easily understood, and is as follows:--
column3: The standard of points as laid down by the leading club is sufficiently explicit to be easily understood, and is as follows:--

column2: GENERAL APPEARANCE--The Dalmatian should represent a strong, muscular, and active dog, symmetrical in outline, and free from coarseness and lumber, capable of great endurance combined with a fair amount of speed.
column3: GENERAL APPEARANCE-The Dalmatian should represent a strong, muscular, and active dog, symmetrical in outline, and free from coarseness and lumber, capable of great endurance combined with a fair amount of speed.

column2: MUZZLE--The muzzle should be long and powerful; the lips clean, fitting the jaws moderately close.
column3: MUZZLE-The muzzle should be long and powerful; the lips clean, fitting the jaws moderately close.

column2: THE RIM ROUND THE EYES in the black-spotted variety should be black, in the liver-spotted variety brown--never flesh-colour in either.
column3: THE RIM ROUND THE EYES in the black spotted variety should be black, in the liver spotted variety brown-never flesh colour in either.

column2: EARS--The ears should be set on rather high, of moderate size, rather wide at the base, and gradually tapering to a round point.
column3: EARS-The ears should be set on rather high, of moderate size, rather wide at the base, and gradually tapering to a round point.

column2: They should be carried close to the head, be thin and fine in texture, and always spotted--the more profusely the better. NOSE--The nose in the black-spotted variety should always be black, in the liver-spotted variety always brown.
column3: They should be carried close to the head, be thin and fine in texture, and always spotted-the more profusely the better. NOSE-The nose in the black spotted variety should always be black, in the liver spotted variety always brown.

column2: LEGS AND FEET--The legs and feet are of great importance.
column3: LEGS AND FEET-The legs and feet are of great importance.

column2: The fore-legs should be perfectly straight, strong, and heavy in bone; elbows close to the body; fore-feet round, compact with well-arched toes (cat-footed), and round, tough, elastic pads.
column3: The fore legs should be perfectly straight, strong, and heavy in bone; elbows close to the body; fore feet round, compact with well arched toes (cat footed), and round, tough, elastic pads.

column2: TAIL--The tail should not be too long, strong at the insertion, and gradually tapering towards the end, free from coarseness.
column3: TAIL-The tail should not be too long, strong at the insertion, and gradually tapering towards the end, free from coarseness.

column2: It should not be inserted too low down, but carried with a slight curve upwards, and never curled.
column3: It should not be inserted too low down, but carried with a slight curve upwards, and never curled.

column2: It should be spotted, the more profusely the better.
column3: It should be spotted, the more profusely the better.

column2: COLOUR AND MARKINGS--These are most important points.
column3: COLOUR AND MARKINGS-These are most important points.

column2: The ground colour in both varieties should be pure white, very decided, and not intermixed.
column3: The ground colour in both varieties should be pure white, very decided, and not intermixed.

column2: The spots should not intermingle, but be as round and well-defined as possible, the more distinct the better; in size they should be from that of a sixpence to a florin.
column3: The spots should not intermingle, but be as round and well defined as possible, the more distinct the better; in size they should be from that of a sixpence to a florin.

column2: WEIGHT--Dogs, 55 lbs.; bitches, 50 lbs.
column3: WEIGHT-Dogs, fifty five pounds.; bitches, fifty pounds.
